awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Integration in Statistical Learning and Data Mining
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF supported REU Site will provide undergraduate students interdisciplinary research experience in statistical learning and data mining with applications in computer vision and pattern recognition at the University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW), for ten weeks during each summer of 2017-2019. UNCW has an institutional commitment to undergraduate education and research through applied learning, and is ideally suited to provide a complete REU experience for the participants. This project is motivated by the shortage of data scientists with analytical skills, recent surge of interests from students, and bringing in awareness of data science career options in academics, industry, and government. The program is designed to involve students in undergraduate research experiences through applied learning and to provide opportunities to develop quantitative and critical thinking skills, and opportunities to improve effective communication skills with professionals from other disciplines.   
 
The intellectual focus of the program is to introduce contemporary statistical learning theory and data mining techniques, with applications in analyzing human facial features. Students will be given lectures on the significant impact of computer vision and pattern recognition, challenges in human image analysis, review of fundamentals in mathematics and statistics, image preprocessing, and contemporary statistical learning theory and data mining techniques. The following topics will be discussed in detail: data cleaning and visualization, dimension reduction, regression and classification, software engineering, high performance computing, etc. Research projects are applications of these techniques and emphasize on real world application with interdisciplinary integration. The values of the problem, background, modeling assumptions, statistical theory, numerical solutions, and visualization with computational technology and its interpretation will be well articulated among the participants. Critical and reflective thinking are encouraged, under proper intervenes by mentors, through team-based collaboration and cooperation, group meetings and feedback from weekly presentation and reports.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Wilmington
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT WILMINGTON

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
From 2017-2021, REU grant has supported 25 student-participants in four  research areas: Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, Deep Learning, Biomedical Science, and Biostatistics.

Overall, the gender includes: 13 female and 12 male particpants. The ethnicities include: 3 female African-American, 1 female Hispanic (withdraw after two weeks due to family emergency), 5 Asian-American (4 female and 1 male), with the rest Caucasian or Others. Of 24 participants, 7 entered Ph.D. program, and 9 entered master program, while the rest have not yet updated us on their status.

 

Five refereed publications:

Kempfert, K. C., Wang, Y., Chen, C., & Wong, S. W. (2020). A comparison study on nonlinear dimension reduction methods with kernel variations: Visualization, optimization and classification. Intelligent Data Analysis, 24(2), 267-290.

Werther, C., Ferguson, M., Park, K., Kling, T., Chen, C., & Wang, Y. (2018, December). Gender Effect on Face Recognition for a Large Longitudinal Database. In 2018 IEEE International Workshop on Information Forensics and Security (WIFS) (pp. 1-7). 

Smith, P., & Chen, C. (2018, December). Transfer learning with deep CNNs for gender recognition and age estimation. In 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data) (pp. 2564-2571). 

Huang, R., Pedoeem, J., & Chen, C. (2018, December). YOLO-LITE: a real-time object detection algorithm optimized for non-GPU computers. In 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data) (pp. 2503-2510).

Yip, B., Bingham, G., Kempfert, K., Fabish, J., Kling, T., Chen, C., & Wang, Y. (2018, December). Preliminary Studies on a Large Face Database. In 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data) (pp. 2572-2579).

 

24 participants gave a total of 64 presentations in international, national, and regional professional conferences and meetings, including but not limited to:

(1) Joint Statistics Meetings (JSM) with three presentations,

(2) Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM),

(3) 2018 IEEE International Conference on Big Data, REU Symposium, in Seattle WA, three presentations,

(4) Women in Statistics and Data Science,

(5) Annual UNCG Regional Mathematics and Statistics Conference (RMSC),

(6) MAA Southeastern Section Meeting,

(7) MATH REU Conference at Clemson University.

 

Here are some additional notable accomplishments by our REU participants:

•      Kathrine Kempfert, one of our female students from Summer 2017, was awarded an NSF Graduate Fellowship in 2020. She started her Ph.D. studies at UC Berkeley in Fall 2019. She won the Best Undergraduate Oral Presentation Awards in the 13th Annual UNCG Regional Mathematics and Statistics Conference (RMSC) in November 2017. She was awarded the ISTI Fellowship to participate in the Information Science Technology Institute both 2018 and 2019 Parallel Computing Summer Research Internship at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

•      Cyera Taylor, one of our female African-American students from Summer 2018, was awarded American Economic Association Summer Program at Michigan State University for Summer 2019. She started her Ph.D. studies in Economics at University of Maryland Baltimore County in Fall 2019.

•      Jericho Lawson, one of our students from Summer 2019, won Best Undergraduate Oral Presentation Award in 15th Annual UNCG Regional Mathematics and Statistics Conference (RMSC) in November 2019. He started his Ph.D. studies in Applied Statistics at UC Riverside in Fall 2020.

•      Lynn Huang, one of our female students from Summer 2018, won Best Poster Award in 14th Annual UNCG Regional Mathematics and Statistics Conference (RMSC) in November 2018. She started her master studies in Statistics at Iowa State University.

•      Morgan Ferguson, one of our female students from Summer 2017, won Best Undergraduate Oral Presentation Awards in 13th Annual UNCG Regional Mathematics and Statistics Conference (RMSC) in November 2017. She started her master studies in Advanced Analytics at NCSU in Fall 2021.

•      Jonathan Fabish, one of our non-traditional students from Summer 2017, won Best Poster Award in 13th Annual UNCG Regional Mathematics and Statistics Conference (RMSC) in November 2017. He was awarded the NSF-funded Graduate Traineeship program at NCAT in Fall 2017. He started his Ph.D. studies in Statistics at NCSU in Fall 2019.

•      Sue Eledkawi, one of our female African-American students from Summer 2019, started her master studies in Data Science at UNCW in Fall 2020.

•      Philip Smith, one of our students from Summer 2018, won “Making a Difference in NC” award in Spring 2019 at UNCW. He attended the Graduate Education Day event in Raleigh, NC to share his research with state legislators and community partners in 2019. He was awarded UNCW CSURF Undergraduate Travel Award of $1,000 in Fall 2018. He started his master studies in Computer Science in Fall 2019.

•      Jonathan Pedoeem, one of our students from Summer 2018, was accepted to a summer internship in Facebook New York in Facebook AI Research (FAIR) for Summer 2019. He is founder and CEO of company of Evant in Summer 2020, which is an SMS engagement platform for communities serving 60+ communities with over 10K community members on the platform.

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Cuixian Chen
